document.text: sister Southern States, which had already seceded. The call went out for volunteers to defend the firesides of the Old Do minion. Appomattox County responded nobly. A Cavalry Company was formed under the command of Capt. Joel W. Flood, becoming Co. H of the 2nd Va. Cavalry. A Company of Heavy Artillery was formed under Capt. James Robertson. A Company of Infantry under Capt. Thos. P. Mat thews, and another Company was formed under Capt. Wm. H. Abbitt, and quite a number of Appomattox citizens living near the rim of the county joined companies from adjoining coun ties. With hearts aflame and bodies dedicated to the Cause they held dear, they went to the front and shared the destiny of the heroes in Gray. Weakened by casualties, new calls came for volunteers, and long after the war, there was a scarcity of able bodied men in the County. Then came April 9, 1865, and the hand of destiny wrote finis across the scroll of four mighty years of struggle Destiny selected Appomattox for one of the major events oi history. Today there is hardly a town- or village in America, that has not heard of Appomattox. Thus ended in this Coun ty, one of the greatest Civil Wars ever chronicled in the files of Time, and at Appomattox began a new page in the history of America. Military rule was established shortly after April 9, 1865. Al county officers were replaced by military appointees. These were men who were selected upon the recommendation of the incumbents, and were willing to take the Iron Clad Oath. In the fall of 1866, an election was held under the Under wood Constitution, which put into effect the 13th and 14th Amendments to the Constitution of the United States, and a new slate of officers were named. Geo. T. Peers became Clerk Wm. T. Johnson Sheriff W. J. Collins, Commissioner of the Revenue the Office of County Treasurer was created Supervisors were provided for, and the ounty Government, practically as we have it now was estab lished. The ravages of four years of war were apparent, and Ap pomattox along with her sister counties, began to repair the wounds. The following years called forth the character and ability of her people, and the present institutions of our Coun- -y are but a tribute to their untiring labor and foresight. document.text: Jesdte Floyd McFadden GLADSTONE - Jessie Floyd M cFadden, 74, of Route 2, Gladstone, died Wednesday, June 8, 1983, in Lynchburg General Hospital. He was born in Buckingham County, a son of the late John William and Ella Marshall McFad den. He was a member of Gladstone Baptist Church and at one time worked for the Charles Russell Brown store in Gladstone. He is survived by five sisters, Mrs. Anna Proffitt, Mrs. Margaret Horsley, and Mrs. Mary Reed Turner, all of Gladstone, Mrs. Belle Woody, Goochland, and Mrs. Ida Sink, Bedford County. Funeral services were conducted at 3 p.m. Friday from Robinson Funeral Home, Appomattox, by the Rev. Jam es N. Williams, with burial in the McFadden family cemetery at Gladstone. Robinson Funeral Home was in charge of arrangements.

Hall left for Nortn Carolina on Monday for an extended stay. Mrs. Hall is visiting relatives in the south. Mr. and Mrs. R. S. Ellis have gone to Atlanta, Ga., on a visit to Dr. James N. Ellis. Mr. 8 . R. Bondurant has gone to West Virginia hoping to obtain a lucrative pos . turn in that state. Mr. R. A. Hull, who has bad a short stay at home, will resume his traveling work this week. M i  b . M. M. Rogers expects to re turn very Boon to her old home, Serchon. She will be welcomed back by her many friends in this community. Prof. Mack, accompaniel by his friend, Mr. John Horsley, paid the neighborhood a flying visit last week. I hear that the public schools will be extended a month longer in this county. I hope this is true, as too much attention cannot be given to education. Rev. C. M. Barrell paid his mem bers in this community a visit last week. He is doing a good and ac ceptable work among his people in and around his cbnrch at Bucking ham.

The chairman then appointed the following committee on resolutions S. L. Ferguson, J. R. Horsley and L. E. Smith. The following resolutions were offered and adopted By S. L. FergusonResolved that it is the sense of this Demo cratic Mass Meeting, assembled at Appomattox Court House on May 1st. 1912, for the purpose of se lecting delegates aud alternates to the Democratic State Convention, which meets in Norfolk May 23rd, 1912, that the delegates and alter nates which have been elected, go to said Convention utunstructed, vote as a unit, and those who are present at said Convention, cast the vote of said delegation as a unit. By Dr. J. B. AbbittResolved that the course of our Unied States Senators, Hon. Thomas S Martin and Hon. Claude A. Swanson, in the Congress of the United States, Oas been nch as to commend it self to the people of Virginia, and we heartily endorse each of them as able and faithful representatives of the people and of Demncatic prin ciples. ByL, E. S.rithResolved that it is the sense of this Democratic mass meeting assembled that the administration of William Hodges .Mann, Governor of Virginia has oeen able and conservative. Resolved, That he has shown him self especially the friend of the farmer in advocating and securing special legislation in tfie interest of the agricnltnrai classes and the bet terment of the agricultural interests of Virginia. By J. R. HorsleyResolved, That Hon. J. Taylor Ellyson has served the Democratic party of Virginia ar chairman of the State Democratic Committee with unselfish z al and ability. Resolved, That, we hear ily en dorse Mr. Ellyson for re-election as chairman of the State Democratic committee and also as a member of the National Democratic committee By. J. IV. CawthomRes lived, That we, the Democratic voters of Appomattox county in mass-meet ing assembled heartily endorse Hon H. D. Flood for re-election to Con gress from the Tenth Virginia Dist rict. Resolved, That this District never had a more able and faithful representative in Congress, or one who has been more active or anc- cessful in representing the interests of his oonstionents. The meeting was a very harmoni ous affair and there was no attempt to instruct the delegates, and it is felt that all the delegates desire to be for the man who can win a Democratic victory.

Murphy says when the fruit year is at hand there will be fruit no matter how cold it gets. Mrs. Wiley Mornss and Mrs. William Horner have been on a visit to their parents, Mr. and Mrs. L D. Jones at New Store the past week. Judge John R. Moss attended Cumberland court looking after his political fences. All ladies are allowed to change their minds and the date for hold ing the High School final has been changed to the 9th of May. The pupils have been well drilled in the parts they are to take and unless some of them are Stage Struck we are to have a nice entertainment.
